content: How can I help you today?
I've been having trouble sleeping lately. I feel like my mind just won’t stop racing, and it's making everything worse. My partner suggested I talk to someone, so here I am.

Thank you for sharing that. It sounds like your racing thoughts and trouble sleeping have been really weighing on you. Taking the step to talk about it here shows a lot of courage and willingness to explore what’s going on. How long has this been happening for you?

It’s been going on for a few months now, and it feels like it’s just getting worse. Every night I lie in bed worrying about work and how I might lose my job. Then I’ll distract myself with my phone, but that just makes it harder to settle down.

It sounds like your worries about work have been overwhelming at night, and trying to distract yourself with your phone hasn’t made it easier to unwind. This has been building up for months, and it seems like it’s affecting you quite a bit. What impact has all of this had on your life or how you’re feeling during the day?

During the day, I just feel exhausted. I can’t focus at work, which makes me even more anxious because I know I’m not performing well. Then I come home and feel like I don’t have the energy to really be present with my kids or my partner. It’s like everything is piling up, and I don’t know how to stop it.

It sounds like the exhaustion and anxiety from sleepless nights are impacting your work and also your time with your family, leaving you juggling a lot. That must feel so heavy, especially when it seems hard to find relief. What do you think might help you feel less stuck in this cycle, even if it feels like a small step right now?

Honestly, I have no idea what might help. I feel like I’ve tried so many things, like avoiding caffeine or going to bed earlier, but nothing works. I guess I feel like maybe fixing the stress at work would help, but that feels completely out of my control. It’s hard to even know where to start with all of this.

It sounds like you've been putting effort into trying different strategies, but you haven't felt much improvement, and the work stress feels overwhelming and hard to manage. That sense of not knowing where to start can make everything feel even more stuck. What you’ve shared is really important—acknowledging the connection between work stress and sleep trouble is a big step. Could you tell me more about what feels out of your control at work?

It’s mostly the worry about layoffs. The company hasn’t said anything officially, but the way things are going with the economy and the pressure I’m under, I just can’t shake this fear that I’m on the chopping block. It’s like every mistake I make at work feels huge, and I can’t relax because I’m constantly afraid it’ll cost me my job.

It sounds like the uncertainty about layoffs and the pressure to not make mistakes has created a constant fear that's really hard to escape. Living with that level of stress day after day must be draining, especially when it feels like you’re carrying it alone. How have you been coping with these fears, or have you found anyone you can talk to about what you're going through?

I haven’t really talked to anyone about it, aside from my partner pushing me to see someone like you. I guess I’ve just been keeping it all bottled up because I don’t want to seem weak or worry anyone. Coping-wise... I don’t know. I just try to push through, even though it’s exhausting.

It sounds like you’ve been trying to hold everything inside, maybe to protect those around you or avoid feeling vulnerable. That must be such an isolating experience, especially since you’ve been carrying this heavy pressure on your own while still trying to push through. Your partner encouraging you to reach out could be a sign of support—they may really care about seeing you feel better. What would it be like to lean on your partner or trust someone close with how you're feeling?

I guess I’m just scared to open up fully. I know my partner cares, but I don’t want to add to their stress or make them feel like they have to fix things for me. Sometimes it feels easier to just keep going and hope it’ll get better on its own, even though it hasn’t so far.

It's understandable to feel hesitant about opening up, especially when you're worried about burdening your partner. You seem like someone who values taking care of others, even when you're struggling yourself. But hoping things will improve on their own has left you feeling stuck for a while. Talking to someone, whether it's your partner or someone else, might give you a space where you don’t have to carry it all alone. Do you think sharing even a little bit could help ease some of that weight?
I think I’m okay to end the conversation. Thank you for speaking about this with me.
